content:
Introduction

Pregnancy of unknown location (PUL) is a term that defines the temporary time from a positive pregnancy test (β-hCG) to before a pregnancy is identified on imaging.  PUL is not a final diagnosis, but is rather a working diagnosis that is used while continued evaluation determines whether the detectable β-hCG represents a normal early intrauterine pregnancy, a failing intrauterine pregnancy (ie, abortion), or an ectopic pregnancy.

Physiology of normal early pregnancy



β-hCG is a hormone secreted by syncytiotrophoblasts that supports and maintains early pregnancy development (

figure 1
).  Levels begin to rise in the maternal serum approximately 8 days following fertilization and become detectable in the urine approximately 14 days following fertilization.  The first 4 weeks following implantation, serum β-hCG levels double roughly every 24-48 hours in a normal intrauterine pregnancy.  The rate of β-hCG rise slows after this and peaks around 8-10 weeks gestation (
figure 2
).



Although β-hCG is detected early following fertilization, the pregnancy is often not yet visible on imaging.  For normal intrauterine pregnancies, the pregnancy typically becomes detectable when the fetus reaches a certain size, which generally correlates to a quantitative β-hCG level ≥3,500 mIU/mL.  This is known as the discriminatory zone, which is the threshold at which a gestational sac should be visible on ultrasonography.



Therefore, patients with a positive pregnancy test and no localizable pregnancy are classified as having a PUL.  PUL may represent a normal early intrauterine pregnancy, a failing intrauterine pregnancy (ie, abortion), or an extrauterine pregnancy (ie, ectopic pregnancy).  Therefore, both the expected β-hCG rate of rise and the discriminatory zone are important factors in evaluating an individual with a PUL.

Differential diagnosis and clinical presentation



The 3 possible outcomes of PUL include:



  • Normal early intrauterine pregnancy:  This is characterized by early pregnancy symptoms (eg, breast tenderness, fatigue, nausea).  Light vaginal bleeding (ie, "spotting") may occur due to blastocyst implantation.  The β-hCG levels rise normally, at least double every 48 hours, and the pregnancy becomes visible on ultrasonography when the discriminatory zone (β-hCG ≥3,500 mIU/mL) is reached.
  • Abortion:  This failing intrauterine pregnancy can occur before evidence of an intrauterine pregnancy and is typically characterized by cessation of early pregnancy symptoms and declining or abnormally rising β-hCG levels.  There is often subsequent painless and light vaginal bleeding.
  • Ectopic pregnancy:  Ectopic pregnancies occur when the blastocyst implants in any location other than the uterine decidua (
    figure 3
    ).  Ectopic pregnancies have abnormally rising β-hCG levels (<50% every 24-48 hr) due to impaired blastocyst growth.

Evaluation



Evaluation of a PUL begins with a comprehensive history and physical examination.  The history includes all current symptoms (eg, abdominal pain and location, vaginal bleeding, nausea/vomiting), last menstrual period, and menstrual cycle regularity.  It also includes a detailed history to assess the risk factors for ectopic pregnancy (eg, previous ectopic, tubal surgery, prior pelvic inflammatory disease, smoking).



The physical examination focuses on an abdominal assessment for tenderness or signs of intraabdominal bleeding (eg, guarding, rebounding) and a pelvic evaluation to evaluate for uterine size, cervical dilation, vaginal bleeding, and adnexal masses or tenderness.

Laboratory studies and imaging



The most important laboratory level is a quantitative serum β-hCG level.  However, a single measurement of β-hCG at <3,500 mIU/mL is often insufficient to determine the location or viability of a pregnancy; therefore, β-hCG levels are often repeated every 48 hours until the discriminatory zone is reached.  The rate of rise is suggestive of the type of pregnancy:



  • β-hCG level doubles:  Suggests a normal intrauterine pregnancy.
  • β-hCG level plateaus (minimal change or slow rise or fall):  Suggests an ectopic pregnancy or a nonviable intrauterine pregnancy (abortion).
  • β-hCG level decreases:  Suggests spontaneously resolving ectopic pregnancy or abortion.


In addition, a quantitative serum β-hCG also helps interpret ultrasonographic findings.  The goals of ultrasonography in early pregnancy are to identify the location of the pregnancy, establish the number of fetuses, and confirm viability.  In very early pregnancy, transvaginal ultrasonography is most commonly used because it provides better imaging of the uterine cavity.



  • β-hCG below the discriminatory zone (<2,000 mIU/mL):  The uterus may be empty, or nonspecific findings may be present (eg, pseudogestational sac [centrally located fluid collection], endometrial thickening, no adnexal masses).
  • β-hCG above the discriminatory zone (≥2,000-3,500 mIU/mL):  If a viable intrauterine pregnancy exists, at minimum, a gestational sac is visible.  An empty uterus and a β-hCG level above the discriminatory zone likely indicate either a failing intrauterine pregnancy or an ectopic pregnancy.

Management



PUL management is based on the suspicion or likelihood of ectopic pregnancy.  Low-risk individuals (no pelvic pain, no adnexal mass, β-hCG below discriminatory zone) can be managed with serial β-hCG levels and repeat transvaginal ultrasonography.  The β-hCG trend determines further components of expectant management:



  • β-hCG rising appropriately:  Repeat ultrasonography is performed several days later or after β-hCG surpasses the discriminatory zone to evaluate for an intrauterine pregnancy.
  • β-hCG abnormally rising or declining:  β-hCG levels are trended until negative, indicating pregnancy resolution.  Because a viable pregnancy is unlikely, patients with an abnormal rise in β-hCG can undergo diagnostic dilation and curettage, which determines pregnancy location based on the intrauterine contents.  The contents of a nonviable intrauterine pregnancy (including recent complete spontaneous abortion) have chorionic villi.  In contrast, the intrauterine contents associated with an ectopic pregnancy have no chorionic villi due to extrauterine pregnancy implantation.


Individuals with moderate to high risk for ectopic pregnancy (pelvic pain, tender adnexal mass, risk factors for ectopic pregnancy) are substratified based on their hemodynamic stability.  Patients whose condition is unstable undergo volume resuscitation and emergency surgery.  In contrast, those whose condition is stable are managed either medically (methotrexate) or surgically, depending on patient preference or contraindication to medical management.

Prognosis



Approximately 50% of pregnancies that begin as PUL never have the location determined, 5%-20% are eventually identified as an ectopic pregnancy, and 30%-45% are identified as either a viable or nonviable intrauterine pregnancy.  A persistent PUL refers to a pregnancy that neither resolves spontaneously nor becomes visible on ultrasonography; these are approached as both a nonviable intrauterine pregnancy and an ectopic pregnancy and are usually treated with a uterine evacuation (for nonviable intrauterine pregnancy) with/without methotrexate (for ectopic pregnancy).  A minimal number of these pregnancies may lead to tubal rupture from an unidentified ectopic pregnancy.

Summary



Pregnancy of unknown location is a working, temporary diagnosis during the time from a positive pregnancy test (β-hCG) to before a pregnancy is identified on imaging.  The 3 possible outcomes include a normal early intrauterine pregnancy, an intrauterine pregnancy (ie, abortion), or an ectopic pregnancy.  Patients are managed based on the risk for ectopic pregnancy, along with serial β-hCG measurements and repeat ultrasonography until a diagnosis is determined.
